In short- because I really could write for ages - we met with rude staff on the station concourse - from complaining we didnt have our tickets out at the ready, to being told to put our golf clubs in our room (you seen the size of the rooms) frustratingly- she saw us walk 6 carriages to our room with our clubs and didnt have the courtesy to save the journey and put them in the travel compartment.  Then, drinks ordered from our room- 30 mins later, still didnt arrive- went to find out where our order was and was met by these rude staff again claiming no order was made ???????unbelievable. then he claims no food or drink was delivered to the train for that service.  Speechless.  in the morning, a coffee and bacon sandwich presented to our door- but no breakfast option as per the website service. Oddly enough, the bacon made it to the train.  Emailed later to complain, full of apologies from Evie re my treatment - will look into it -etc    reply came back several weeks later ( i had to chase) and I quote " weve looked into it and dealt with it, cant divulge what we have done and wont offer you any compensation. Hope this is satisfactory and trust it will not put you off travelling with us again"     
Honestly - lost for words.  I have since rang back 4 times wishing to speak to the manager- Jane - still hasnt called me back.   Matter now with Ombudsman.   absolutely shocking service.

items.title: Great trip, really enjoyed it!
items.review_text:
Travelled from Euston to Fort William in November, after booking tickets my wife checked reviews and was so put off by the reviews on Trust Pilot she nearly cancelled and opted for a flight! Writing this review to balance things up as we had a genuinely wonderful trip that we will repeat - we now think it’s the only way to travel to the highlands. Firstly, it’s worth suggesting that don’t have too high expectations, this is not the Orient Express, it’s not perfect but for the money, a great value trip with some very pleasing surprises. 

- Wonderful welcome by friendly staff
- Well appointed room, comfy bed and pillow (I’m only 5’8 so tall people may disagree)
- Hard seats in the club car but great service, good half bottle Cotes du Rhone and a cheese board, bliss, great service again.
- on board WiFi worked well enough (Though I downloaded a movie ahead of time)
- my wife used the ear plugs and eye mask provided and slept well, woken briefly a few times. I found it a bit harder, a combination of the back lit button on my control panel (which I covered with a T-shirt) and the jolting train kept me awake but I caved in and used mask and plugs and then slept well (a lesson learned).
-waking up to the morning gloom of the highlands was unforgettable
- you are supposed to order breakfast when you board which we forgot to do but the staff had extra (I guess they always get one like me) and produced a delicious highland breakfast (and that view!).

Not the smoothest of rides but it’s a train.. would be cramped for bigger taller people but all in all, this is a really terrific service and I will definitely be using it again!

items.title: My seated coach review
items.review_text:
My seated coach review: 
Want enough light to read and just the right amount to keep you awake? Then this train is perfect for you. They keep the lights on all night 5*. Do you enjoy that feeling of holding for the toilet? Excellent, my train has a blocked toilet and as bottom class I wasn’t allowed to use the other, 5*. Need a night time wake up call? You’re in the right place. Just as I managed to get some sleep at 2:30am, shortly after, a staff member shouting came in to announce a change of carriage for those leaving in a few hours. They woke me up to check if I was one of those, which I wasn’t. The worst night sleep in years and I’ve slept above night clubs. Don’t do it - fly instead.

items.title: booking process faults
items.review_text: I’m complaining about the booking process. I haven’t travelled anywhere. I can’t work out how to book, or find out how much it costs, or see a timetable.

items.title: Made my first journey on the new…
items.review_text: Made my first journey on the new sleepers, in Club First. On the day of departure I received a text telling me that there would be no food service in the Lounge car due to "last minute staff shortage". (This was some nine hours before departure....very last-minute)  The new Lounge Car has hard and uncomfortable seats and is clearly intended to get you out of there asap. The "shower" was like a badly made cheap child's toy. 45 seconds of water then you have to push the taps again. Took five attempts before the water was tepid. The shower soaks the floor so if you go to the loo in the middle of the night you'll get your feet very wet! I was woken around 0100 by water pouring on to my face from a leak in the cabin. I had to get dressed and move all my stuff to another cabin, so not much sleep. The promised showers and toilets at the Virgin Lounge at Euston were not functioning and apparently hadn't been for some time. The ticket was £182. The refund was £55, and I had to hold on the phone for 15 minutes just to get that authorised.  The three people who crewed the entire Glasgow to London sleeper that night did their best but it seems that management are simply not up to running a railway.

items.title: Awful breakfast and ladder rungs need padding
items.review_text:
Breakfast:
Two years ago my husband and I took the Caledonian Sleeper from Inverness to London. It was during covid so we could understand the very basic breakfast that was included in our price. This time, however, we had different expectations and we looked forward to a nice breakfast in the club car. I had pre-ordered the salmon omelette with avocado and sourdough toast, which sounded really good. Sadly, it was appalling – the omelette was the size of the palm of my hand, was lukewarm and rubbery. It had clearly been made long beforehand. Then, not only was the accompanying avocado obviously very brown and overripe, but it actually tasted rotten! Luckily I had a very nice looking piece of toast to save the day – or so I thought! Alas it came with no butter and when I asked for some I was told there wasn’t any. Really? Dry toast? Possibly one is expected to put the omelette on the toast to give it some moisture, but the omelette was so dry it would have helped diddlysquat. I heard other people also asking for butter but they too received a negative response. 
My husband had the bacon roll. Once again no butter, simply a sliced white breadroll with 2 pieces of bacon shoved inside. No accompanying sauces either. He said it was like eating cardboard. I felt sorry for the people travelling on a non-inclusive breakfast who would have had to fork out £5.25 for this!  

Bunk ladders:
Last time we travelled we had the double cabin but this time we had the double bunks. My husband and I are quite small people so the bunks were fine for us and actually I found them really cosy to sleep in. However, be warned - you need to be quite agile to get on and off the top bunk, and to add to the difficulty the ladder rungs are very narrow steel which really hurts bare feet! Surely putting on a small bit of padding can’t be that difficult?

items.title: I should stress this is a review about…
items.review_text:
I should stress this is a review about Sleeper seats not about a sleeper cabin. Warning! Don’t book a Sleeper Seat!!! It may be cheap but it’s a terrible experience. The seats do not recline. There is no headrest and worse still there are no wings on the seats. The arm rest cannot be moved and the seats are situated in such a position that you can’t even rest your head against the window. 
Worst of all if you are in a Sleeper Seat you are treated like a steerage passenger on the Titanic. You are not allowed anywhere near the dining car and I was told I could not buy food to take back to my seat. There was no drinks service available. Thank God I had taken plenty of water. A terrible terrible experience rather like being in a prison cell for the night. Whoever designed the so called sleeper seats should be made to sit in one from Euston to Inverness and back! 
I have also travelled on this service in a berth. It was the old carriages.  I went from Crewe to Fort William return.as I boarded at Crewe at midnight. Obviously I did not have the same experience as if I had boarded at Euston. The return journey was good and I was able to sit in the dining car and have a lovely meal. It was rather lovely as the scenery is spectacular and it was like something out of an old film. 
I have heard horror stories though about the upgraded service ie even if you have a sleeper berth you cannot get into the dining car and when you eventually do there is no food available.

items.title: Bring back the OLD sleeping cars.
items.review_text:
With so many reports of this service being unstable in its reliability, I decided to fly down from Inverness to London and chance my return by Caledonian Sleeper.
The train is scheduled to depart Euston at 21.15 with boarding at 20.30. A text message was received indicating boarding will not commence until 21.00. However no indication that boarding was commencing by 21.00 so we headed to platform one where a gathering of around 20 persons had already arrived. Staff could be seen speaking back and fore on there own radios.
I just hoped there was no issues arising. Boarding was permitted by 21.25. Departure at 21.35. (20mins late, but ok with me as long as it keeps going).
Inside our 'classic twin' which is the same as old bunk compartment but smaller in width to the old cabins, a full length mirror on reverse of door to make it look bigger. A vertical ladder which will not be of use to many senior, frail or less active passengers. A cumbersome sink at the window (the old coaches was a fold up one) a pullout tray which sticks on return and 3 pieces of literature (menus, etc) which can only be left on top of your bed and then on the floor. The design inside is very much thrown together. A switch cluster has internal light press and call for assistance press right beside each other, yes in the dark you can easily call for assistance while intending to only switch the light on hmm!
The coach suspension is 'bouncy' and noisier than before like some sort of generator noise. The only improvement i could see was a better heating control.
Staff are reasonably helpful but could enforce quiet speech when traversing corridors, so annoying and at midnight at Crewe a female steward started shouting at someone on the platform as if the person was deaf.
Its a shame the service is so unreliable especially when the service it replaced was not always perfect but was stable.
My verdict is it needs to go back into a train operating company like Scotrail who can draw staff in emergency rather than Serco who use GBRF a rail freight company for the loco and loco staff with few staff north of the border.
Oh, and it really is over-priced.

items.title: If I could have marked zero stars I…
items.review_text: If I could have marked zero stars I would! We were very excited for our very expensive Caledonian Sleeper experience given the fact the return costs were the same price as a holiday abroad! We were met at the platform by a very nice attendant who showed us to our cabin and then took our breakfast orders…. Breakfast is limited due to staff shortages?? He then advised we are welcome to go along to the lounge for a drink, which we did… entered an empty carriage to be directed to a single table by the waiter…. There were plenty booths however he wanted us as far away from where he and his boss were sitting so we couldn’t hear him browsing tik tok! We ordered a couple of drinks and were told last orders at 12am my colleague and I then moved to a more comfortable booth to allow us to review business docs on iPad to be told “we don’t allow 2 people to sit in booths normally”…… there was no one else in the carriage! We then decided to order a sandwich to take back to our room to be told “there is no food, only snacks, well only olives…. Did you not get the text? It’s because we are short staffed” we then asked to order another drink whereby he looked at us like this was scandalous and said “well you need to pay” (he never asked us to pay for the first round at the point) then looked at his watch (checking if it was 12am so he did not need to serve us!)(he had 13 mins before 12am and looked very annoyed at this fact!)  clearly very obvious the customer service is not important, nor is speaking to people in a polite and courteous manner, let alone providing the service advertised by this rail line! Absolutely shocking, a first time experience ruined by people who should not be in a customer facing role, we were not made to feel welcomed or relaxed in the first hour of our sleeper experience!!! Would not recommend!!!

items.title: A wasted design oppotunity
items.review_text:
Couldn't wait to try the Caledonian Sleeper service, using the new rolling stock, as loved the old ones we used from the 1980s onwards to and from Inverness and London. Now we live in Invernesshire, this seemed the best way to come back from London, so didn't get back in the dark at night, but in the morning, refreshed, instead. 

Not great at Euston, as only went up on board 15 mins beforehand, then a rush to find the platform and the right sleeping apartment. The Scotsman at barrier was charming, the attendant seeing us onto the train and ticking us off list, not so, on the rude side of disorganised. The standard sleeping room, two bunk beds, which we used to travel on, not that well re-designed, in fact the old design was better. The ladder is dead straight against the bunks, making it hard to get up to top one (used to be sloping and allow more space at bottom too). The hard metal stand for putting mobile devices in, against each bedhead, is a treat to head injuries. The padded sides that used to keep you safely in the top bunk as gone, the small thingey now replacing it, makes turning over in bed deadly. OK, we accept, not the real china cups anymore for morning tea/coffee, but the cardboard versions feel cheap and tacky and are they even recycled? I did manage the bathroom door, everyone else was complaining about getting in through the strange folding doors, but the loo was very noisy and nearly sucked you in too! The sleeping room was noisy due to the wheels sounding like they were coming off, didn't sound too safe and very bumpy compared to the old rolling stock. Could have done with mirrors and hooks in better places and just a lot more thought, this feels very basic, but an idea way to travel, which used to be a delight. The staff, very sadly, need some training in how to talk to people too, this makes so much difference to what should be a pleasant experience. However, managed to sleep, despite all this, as for some strange reason, I always sleep better in moving trains and ships that at home in bed!

items.title: "Sleeper?" Oh the irony.
items.review_text:
"Sleeper?" Oh the irony.

Travelled from London Euston to Aberdeen in late March 2022 with my partner. The double club room was comfortable, (when the train was stationary). 
The double-ish bed was very comfortable and plenty of under-bed storage to fit a couple of suitcases. However, there's absolutely no room to move around. It took half an hour for our evening food order to be taken, when I complained the waiter huffed and muttered down his nose at us. He was generally abrupt and rude at the evening sitting AND breakfast. The journey was SO uncomfortable. You can't sleep on this train and it feels that the carriage isn't dampened because you feel every bump and movement. There was a continual whistling coming from the air vent that I had to shove a towel into to muffle the sound a little. However, as much as we tried we couldn't sleep, even with earplugs. The lights around the buttons on the instrument panel are too bright and totally illuminate the room at night.
The food, drink and service on this service is poor, it's overpriced, the food is bland and if you're vegetarian or vegan forget it, there's a singular option for you and you can't get a cooked veggie breakfast. I asked the waiter why wasn't there more options for veggies and asked what cooked breakfasts they had without meat who responded with "You can have the Eggs Royale that's got salmon in it but no meat." 
"Salmon IS meat" I said, "It's fish". "Ok, you can have Eggs Royale with no fish then". The service ran on time but I would NOT recommend this service to anyone wanting a peaceful journey. The only good thing was waking up to the incredible Scottish scenery - other than that I would have given this review a one star. They need to bring this service into the 21st Century or just call it a day. For £240 a person we felt pretty ripped off and let down. Never again.

items.title: Shocking
items.review_text:
First of all let me start with saying the staff was a total pleasure and is not a reflection on them in the slightest. 

The route was the most bumpiest we have ever had even on the east coast it was very bumpy making resting so very impossible. You feel very much like the word comfort is so hard.

When the trains had to be joined at Edinburgh nobody came to tell us why, nothing on the on screen display leaving a fellow passenger to fill me in. My family was wondering as this is different from other journeys.

Then a passenger was very drunk and was making accusations to a fellow passenger about taking videos of content he shouldn’t, he was very rude and called either the member of staff or passenger a “ racist c..t “ which is not acceptable. They was debating this with him for nearly 40 mins about what he did and drinking alcohol. Now they didn’t remove the accused passenger. 

We was left with a man whose behaviour was intimidating, and could therefore turn on other passengers including ourselves. Then we had to wait to leave as we was told we couldn’t leave the door they waited on BTP. But they left us with the passenger totally not caring for our safety or checking how we felt. He should have been removed at Newcastle where we stopped but he wasn’t. Imagine how scary that would feel if it was yourselves. 

It was combination or that and people playing on the next night back home to glasgow of people at 3am watching Spanish soaps loud and lying across the floor H6B/C and the guy from 2C constantly walking up and down the carriage very freaky. This made the journey not fun or relaxing. It’s like we do plan to use the service in the future maybe the rooms but the seats for £277 as I said wasnt fun or enjoyable. 

We only just finally get the sleep we need. Both my sister and I having epilepsy and autism and my my with anxiety this did impact this

items.title: Travelled on 2115 departure from Euston…
items.review_text:
Travelled on 2115 departure from Euston to Fort William on Tuesday 7th January...I'm an OAP and paid nearly £300 return for a basic cabin. At just before 7am a knock on my door telling me train had broken down and to get all my belongings and go to buffet. No electric...no hot drinks...no heating...the failure of the electrics locked all the toilets. We waited 2.5 hours for road transport. The train had stopped at an unmanned tiny station....I wasn't offered any assistance and walked down 25 slippery stairs..it was raining and I had a bag in each hand so could not hold the rail. There were 12 passengers...we were put on a mini bus with a leaking roof the rain water had soaked the seats had to sit on that for 1.5 hours. What a way to travel in 2020. The return journey that night was replaced by a coach journey from Fort William to Edinburgh and you then got onto a train. How often is this happening. This incident wasn't reported on Thier website. They reserve the right to take up to 10 days to reply to your email. To top it all I've now got a severe cold. Just a nightmare!   Forgot to add I paid for a breakfast when I joined the train at Euston....didn't get it wasn't offered a refund because they couldn't open the cash register. B*lls*it!!!  

Since I wrote this review there have been developments!!! The local newspaper covered it as a major story. Caledonian Sleeper refunded my complete fair and also offered me a free single ticket. I am of the opinion they were very sorry and I will give them another chance. I'm going again in February.....will let you know if I survive!!

items.title: Travelling Club Solo on the new…
items.review_text:
Travelling Club Solo on the new Caledonian Sleeper between London Euston and Glasgow. 
I was down in London for a work trip and thankfully my work had sprung for First Class on the sleeper home. The last time I took a sleeper train was about 20 years ago and we only had seats in the old carriages, so anything was going to be better than that!
With the Club Solo ticket I had access to the First Class Lounge in Euston which I was very thankful for with having 2 hours to kill before my train. In the lounge there were free drinks (non-alcoholic), snacks, comfy chairs and fast, free wifi. 
About 20 minutes before departure I went down to the platform where I was met by a couple of friendly staff members who gave me a keycard for my cabin. 
Inside the cabin itself was big enough for one person, I could put my bag and shoes under the bed, there was charging ports, heating dial, dimmable lights as well as a sink with toiletries and a spray to make your pillow smell nice. There was also an en-suite which could also be used as a shower room, very convenient in the middle of the night when you don't want to roam the corridors looking for a toilet! You also got ear plugs and a sleep mask. 
The bed itself was comfortable and of good quality, there was enough length that a person of my height - 6'4 - could 'just' stretch out, though my feet were up against the wall. The rocking motion of the train wasn't too bad, and the only noise was that of the train tracks. My only complaint really is the width of the bed, I'm quite broad shouldered so I felt a little confined in movement with the bed. The wifi onboard isn't the best either, so for streaming on Netflix I had to just use 4G on my phone. 
Come morning I went along to the Lounge car which was very nice and comfortable, and had my complimentary breakfast which was served at the time I'd requested on my card the night before. Breakfast was delicious as was the coffee. 
All in all it was a pleasant experience, though if I were to do it again I think I would try to get one of the double beds just so I had space to spread myself out a bit more!

items.title: AVOID - CAVEAT EMPTOR
items.review_text:
56% of reviews are 1 star and 15% are 2 star so 71% of reviews are bad - why?  Misleading advertising, overpricing, an uncomfortable and sleepless journey, cramped conditions with a toilet with a mind of its own, this is certainly not a premium product, although at £410 ONE WAY you are certainly paying for one.  I have spent the best part of three months going backwards and forwards with Caledonian Sleeper and the Rail Ombudsman, as I made a formal complaint.  Their decision was final, but it was the wrong decision as it did not address their misleading advertising, uncomfortable journey and lack of any sleep.  I have attempted to instigate proceedings against Caledonian Sleeper via the Claims Court only to find that as they are based in Inverness, Scotland and not in England - there is no way I can sue them using Moneyclaim online.  So, the only recourse I now have is to leave honest reviews online so that others don't go through what we have gone through. 
It is shameful that their advertising and marketing is so far from the truth, and there is nothing which can be done apart from asking my bank to process a chargeback.  Caledonian Sleeper are charging customers ridiculously high amounts to travel and the experience is far from ideal and certainly not as their advertising suggests "wake up feeling refreshed" what a joke - if you get a wink of sleep - that would be one more than we got.  You don't need to believe what I am saying as 71% of reviews left on Trustpilot all can't be wrong with awarding just 1or 2 stars - if there was an option to leave no star I would.

items.title: Seated Class - appalling experience
items.review_text:
As someone who used to love and regularly travel via the Cally sleeper, it pains me to write this. However, the journey I had last week was one of the worst i have ever had. For £75 (and no ability to use a 26-30  railcard - why???) I booked one of the seats (bunks were a. sold out and b. extortionate at a *minimum* of £175), which in itself should not have been an issue, although it does seem strange that an overnight chair (with the journey taking 8hrs) should cost *more* than a normal chair during the day (taking 4.5hrs). However, upon arrival it got worse and worse. In summary: 1) the lights are on full brightness all night, with no means to turn them down or off. This in-built piece of design genius is apparently to ensure "staff safety". What about putting strip lighting on the floor, like on an airplane? Or even just dimming them a bit so that it less resembled sitting inside a filament lightbulb??? 2) The aircon. The carriage was cooled to a temperature more akin to a chilly day on Svalbard than is appropriate for a train journey. I ended up having to put two pairs of trousers on over my arms to stay warm, and even then was shaking with cold all night. It was bizarre, and completely unnecessary. 3) I fail to understand why seated passengers cannot use the restaurant car (though I appreciate this was also the case on the old trains - but still wrong). It was practically empty (understandably - most occupants were tucked up in their double beds!!!) and it seems baffling to keep the 'Great Unwashed Seated Class' in their carriage where the staff have to come and hand deliver their orders (hence keeping the lights on full beam). The staff were just doing their job, but I feel for them as they clearly get these complaints on a regular basis and are powerless to do anything. I would love nothing more than for the Sleeper to become to joyful, incredible journey and experience it once was and should be, but at the moment (in the seated class) it couldn't be further from the truth. Please please please @CaledonianSleeper take note and improve the experience - I would love to see how your executives react to a night in the Seated class and how quickly things might change!!!

*oh and how could I forget, we were delayed by over an hour!!!

items.title: Mattress open to the metal springs and…
items.review_text: Mattress open to the metal springs and I was cut badly, bled all day. When you complain it says 21 days to answer an e-mail? ridiculous. Very Very poor.

items.title: Air conditioning broken, pre-ordered breakfast not available
items.review_text:
The air conditioning was broken on my outward journey. According to the attendant it had been broken for some time and he wasn't very pleased that it hadn't been fixed yet despite his pleas to higher powers for this to happen. I endured a very uncomfortable night during which I was either very hot or, having taken the covers off me and after the temperature had dropped, very cold. I woke up in the morning with a sore throat and hoarseness, and my voice hasn't recovered even now, 10 days later. I can only think that the reason it wasn't fixed in a timely manner has something to do with the fact that the trains are soon to be replaced. On one leg of the only other journey I have made with Caledonian sleeper, there was a problem with the ventilation which meant we had to sleep with the doors open to avoid carbon monoxide poisoning. Presumably some suit in an office somewhere decided it would be a shrewd business move to spend money on advertising the new fleet of trains, rather then rushing to ensure that customers have a comfortable journey in existing trains that will soon go out of use. No refund was offered for the lack of air conditioning.

Additionally, on my return journey the breakfast option I had ordered a month before when booking the journey (and also confirmed on the evening of travel) had run out, and I was given instead a limited choice of 2 options - if I had had any allergies or dietary/religious requirements I could easily have gone hungry. Luckily, as it was I was merely annoyed to have a less good option. Also the breakfast did not come with orange juice as specified. Perhaps this was a mistake but I didn't want to make it awkward by querying this in case the reason was they had run out of this too. I would have thought that if they allow you to pre-order food then they would ensure they had enough of each type of meal to cater for the orders, especially given that many people have dietary restrictions.

items.title: Nightmare journey from Euston to Inverness…
items.review_text:
We travelled from Euston to Inverness in early July. We were really looking forward to the journey and had not read any reviews prior to our trip. We wish we had!!
As we were getting on the train we were told we were only allowed in the buffet lounge if all the seats were not taken by Club class passengers. Presumably we would have been  asked to leave if all the seats were taken and a Club passenger came in. Rather embarrassing. 
However we excitedly opened the door of our Classic cabin only to think that we had walked into a cupboard. It was so small we could only stand behind each other with the rest of the space taken up by the bunk beds. Very claustrophobic.
Somewhat disappointing but we were only there to sleep and our bags fitted under the bottom bunk so we would make the most of it.
Climbing on to the top bunk was not easy. I am fairly fit for a 74 year old but it was even worse coming down. The ladder is fixed almost exactly in the middle  so my wife had to decide how best to get into the bottom bunk as whichever side of the ladder she went she had to be a bit of a contortionist.
We finally got settled down and then the nightmare began. We have never experienced noise like it on a train before. My wife wears hearing aids and even with them out she was unable to get a wink of sleep. 
You can imagine how bad it was for me. 
When the train stopped I just prayed that we might get off to sleep before it started again but it was not to be.
All in all certainly the worst travel experience we have ever had. 
Please do not waste your money . There are better ways to get to Scotland.
When I complained I was told that " we were probably in cabins 1,2, 9 or 10 as they are right over the wheels. Actually we were in 8 but as the cabins are so small none of them are far from the wheels!

items.title: A bitter disappointment both ways
items.review_text:
I've travelled on sleeper trains in the UK (Night Riviera) and in Europe, so I was looking forward to a trip to Edinburgh and back on the Caledonian Sleeper, without any unrealistic expectations of what can be achieved within the cramped dimensions of British rolling stock. I'd read some bad reviews of the new Mark 5 coaches, but went with an open mind.

Things started off badly, when a text message arrived a few minutes before boarding was supposed to commence, explaining that the train had a software fault, and so boarding would be delayed by around an hour. Unfortunately, this message arrived just as all the station bars and cafes at Euston closed for the evening. We then had a miserable, and seemingly open ended wait in the bleak bowels of the station, with no staff to be seen and no announcements. Apparently there was a customer lounge somewhere, but this was only for higher class passengers - 'classic' berth ticket holders shouldn't expect a waiting room, after all, they're only paying £250 per trip...

The ride up to Scotland was awful. Apart from the carriages banging forward and back, and side to side, the bogies (which are directly underneath the 'classic' berths) bang against the underside of the train. When traveling round a bend (there are A LOT of bends on the West Coast mainline), the wheels seem to want to carry on in a straight line - causing a rapid vibration like driving over cobbles. At every crossover and set of points, the wheels hit the rail joints hard, with a bang, and it feels like the carriage is about to derail.

As I say, I've been on a lot of sleeper trains, and I actually enjoy the sensation of sleeping on a moving train, but this isn't it. There seems to be a battle going on each night, between the train and the track, and only one of them is going to win...

We forgot about the rotten journey up and enjoyed a week in Edinburgh, and hoped the journey home would be more like the 'hotel on wheels' advertised. 

Nope.

I've not stayed in a hotel before where the neat, folded towels are smeared with the previous occupant's make-up, or where the immaculately made sheets contain lovely long hairs neither my colour or length. Never mind - off to the club car for a bite to eat and a nightcap. The lovely friendly stewardess came over and listened to our order, before sheepishly explaining that due to a fault, there was no hot water in the club car, and so for hygiene reasons, they could only serve crisps and cold drinks. We opted for a couple of 330ml cans of beer, which at £5 each, were only 350% more expensive than they would have been in the Sainsburys Local outside the station. We went for a bowl of olives to accompany the beer. I thought that it was a bit mean giving us eleven olives to share for £2, surely they could at least given us a dozen so that we had six each. Although my partner pointed out that maybe the portion should have been ten, and they'd given us a bonus olive to be nice.

The journey south replicated the 'oh God, I'm trapped in the spin dryer, when's it going to end?' and 'I don't want to die in a derailment outside Lichfield' vibes of the journey north. We arrived in Euston half an hour early, decided not to indulge in a bag of breakfast crisps in the club car, and slunk off home. 

My partner says she never wants to travel by sleeper again, which is a shame as I know other sleeper trains are far more comfortable, and far cheaper than the Caledonian, but after the trips we just had, I don't know whether I can even convince myself to brave this 'unique experience' again. 
Something urgently needs to be done to address the frightening ride quality and constant technical issues of the rolling stock, which is only a few years old after all. The fact that Caledonian Sleeper management don't respond to any negative feedback suggests that this isn't going to happen. I suspect that any change of power in the Scottish Government will see this expensive service, which fails to be either a high end 'hotel on wheels', or a reliable, economic travel option for ordinary people, will be quietly binned.

items.title: Very Poor Design of Sleeper Rooms. Water in shower cold.
items.review_text:
We were really looking forward to travelling on the new Caledonian Sleeper as have travelled on the older trains quite a lot and looked forward to the new experience. We were hugely disappointed though.

The rooms felt very cramped. We have travelled on the older trains but the new trains feel more cramped. The top bunk is situated too high so it's impossible to sit up in bed, there is no shelf for personal items (watch, wallet, glasses etc.) even though there is space for this. The ladder to the top bunk is completely vertical so it's very hard to climb up/down. We paid to travel in a Club room but was very disappointed that we could not use the shower as the water was way too cold (even after we ran it for a while to see if it would warm up but it didn't) so we paid for a facility which we could not use. It was already November (so a cold month) and then to have a cold shower is not appealing. There is a handy pull-out table but this blocks the entrance to the toilet when in use.

Also, the ride felt VERY bumpy. I could feel the bumps and jolts a lot more than the older Caledonian sleeper train. I also travelled from London Paddington to Penzance on the Night Rivieria sleeper train which was a lot more comfortable. The suspension on the new Caledonian trains seems quite poor. 

It feels that the design of the train was not properly tested with real users otherwise why would the ladder be so vertical and the pull-out table block the toilet/shower door and lack of space to sit up. Where do management expect people to put personal items when sleeping - glasses, watch etc? A small shelf would have been ideal. 

On the plus side:
- Website booking process was easy to use 
- The staff on board the train were really good
- Breakfast was good 
- Bar car was good (seats somewhat hard but may soften with time)
- Food and drinks choices and prices in the bar car was good 
- The toilet in the Club room was really nice to have
- We arrived on time

Overall, in future I would fly - but if you can put up with the downsides this is a novel way to travel between London and Scotland and the staff on board were lovely.

items.title: Just appalling
items.review_text:
Where do I start - confusion on boarding the train - convinced we had booked double room - it said flexible twin on the tickets - were given bunk beds where you needed to be a contortionist to get into the top one - when we questioned the train manager he said ‘ah, lots of people make that mistake’ so it’s almost misrepresentation- beware 
We also had no running water so toilet and wash basin didn’t work and on boarding we were told that the club car/bar was not open for this trip - only to stumble across it later full up with seat paying passengers (nothing against them) but it was a shambles all round.
After a horrid nights sleep we woke to a disorganised breakfast (or excuse for one) with either tea or orange juice (can’t have both) and a breakfast that consisted of microwaved pale looking sausage, an egg rubber circle and an anemic looking price of bacon in a polystyrene carton with a wooden fork - made airplane food look gourmet. We wrote to customer services who did offer a small refund but at the prices charged it was nowhere near enough to make up for the stress - never again

items.title: Sadly disappointing
items.review_text:
Overall the services I was on were quite good. They ran to time and the staff were helpful.

I only write negative reviews when something really irritates me, and here’s what did with this service. I was told to fill out a breakfast card and leave it on my door handle, which I did. I clearly wrote that I wanted my breakfast in the room at 7:30. The guy said that might be too late because the train arrived at 7:49. I advised him that it was a room breakfast so would be packed up and easy to eat or keep if I decided to take it with me (like I did on my previous journey). He then agreed that 7:30 would be fine for that. At around 6:50 someone banged on my door repeatedly- they didn’t get the hint after the first few bangs and just continued to knock.  When I finally told them I was busy (I was in the middle of getting dressed) she opened the door anyway and muttered ‘but what about your breakfast’. I pushed the door closed and told her I had ordered breakfast for 7:30 so to come back then. I didn’t get the breakfast in the end because she obviously couldn’t be bothered coming back with it. I’m unsure why they need me to open the door for it in the first place- it comes in a tiny bag so they could easily hang it on the door handle.

Also, just walking into someone’s room like that is hideous! I had no clothes on at the time, which is bad enough, but if someone was fast asleep it would actually be very frightening for them to have someone walk in like that. And all just to give them a breakfast? Absolute disgrace! You’d think the train was on fire the way she let herself into the room like that! 

Thankfully I didn’t have to pay for my tickets, as they were booked for me, but I definitely wouldn’t book any myself in the future. You’d be cheaper getting an airport hotel for a night and then taking the earliest flight in the morning if you wanted to make the most of your time at your destination. 

It’s also pretty difficult to sleep on a train that feels a lot bumpier than normal trains. The beds are comfortable but the bumpiness of the train cancels that positive out anyway. I can understand why the sleeper reviews are so terrible! 

New dining carriages are also very drab and look like they’ve been designed by someone who designs old people homes! The food there was quite nice but I’m told it’s very unreliable. I actually found that to be true on my return journey as I was messaged to say there would be no hot meals.

items.title: The most civilized way to travel between London and Scotland!
items.review_text:
I was very weary by the reviews everywhere of the Caledonian Sleeper and I was starting to think that maybe I wouldn't enjoy it as much as I hoped I would! I was thankfully wrong.

I travelled from London Euston to Inverness with my partner and caught the 2059 service. You are able to board the train around 30 minutes before departure which is great as you can put your luggage away and start to settle into your journey. 

Boarding was extremely unorganized. Herds of people just wandered outside the train with no information being given to passengers on how to access their room! My partner and I entered our berth for the 12 hour journey to Inverness. My initial thoughts of the room: very clean, cramped but cosy! The room wasn't cold or hot, a lovely temperature for winter. You are also given an amenity kit which consists of an eye-shades, earplugs and a water bottle. There is a control panel next to your bed, which has temperature control, a reading light, power socket, a button to call the host and many more which I can't remember! Once we familiarized ourselves - we tried to activate the lock on our door which took many attempts but we eventually got there. 

We rushed to the dining cart to find out it was nearly full! We hadn't even left London yet! If you want to have dinner on the train, please go to the dining cart as soon you put your luggage away! The dining cart fills up very quickly. We luckily managed to get a booth but the waiter kindly asked us if we would mind sharing it as some other passengers wanted dinner and there were no more tables available! Obviously we didn't mind but please bear this in mind if you're expecting an intimate dinner with your partner! The waiter took some time to get hold of which was understandable as it was very busy already! All the staff I encountered were very professional, friendly and well dressed. I ordered the lamb shacks for the main course and the fruit platter for dessert, both were delicious and the portion sizes were acceptable. The wine menu was decent and the prices were also reasonable for train food, too.

After dinner, we descend into our berth for the night. We had the twin berth. The mattresses were actually not too bad. They weren't as amazing as some luxury hotel mattresses but it was definitely more comfortable than what I had expected! The linen was extremely comfortable, warm and clean! I'm 6ft and I didn't find the bed cramped at all. The noises levels on the train aren't as bad as some people make out (well, I don't think so anyway) I managed to sleep for about 4-5 hours and woke up near Perth. My partner requested tea for breakfast (which is complimentary in all the berths) but sadly - he never received. 

About 10 minutes prior to arrival into Inverness - there was an announcement made to say we will be arriving into Inverness shortly. We arrived bang on time.

If you're looking for something luxurious like the Orient Express, perhaps this isn't it but if you're looking for something which will take you from London to Scotland in a civilized manner - then I would definitely recommend this. The only reason why I haven't given it 5* is because there were a few small things I didn't like, such as the buttons on the carriage doors made an annoying noise every time we alighted at a station! Not something you want to hear when you're trying to sleep! Other than that - I can't wait to travel on the Caledonian Sleeper again!

items.title: Utter Dissapointment
items.review_text:
I travelled with my partner on the sleeper from London Euston to Edinburgh Sunday 19th February 2023. We had planned to do this for a long time and had saved up for the trip.

The problems started when we were in the lounge at Euston station, and there was no mention of our train on the departure boards, only one to Glasgow at the same time. I then received a text to say that our train was delayed and an announcement would be made at the station regarding this journey. No announcement was made and there were still no signs of our train on the board. I contacted customer services via live chat and they said that the train on the board to Glasgow was in fact our train as the Glasgow one had been cancelled. There were still no announcements and we were forced to leave the lounge at 11pm when it shut.

We then waited at the barrier to the platform along with the rest of the train. No explanation was given as to why the train was delayed. After around half an hour a member of Caledonian staff came down the line and said that he had no information as to the delay but asked where we were going. When we replied Edinburgh, he said we were 'lucky' we were not going to Glasgow - no apology was given for the lateness.

We eventually were allowed onto the platform at around midnight - an hour and a half later than planned and were told we could not simply get on the train but had to check in with a member of caledonian staff on the platform. We were totally aghast to hear that the person in front of us was told he could not travel as his carriage had been removed. This caused a great deal of stress for everyone concerned and further delayed those who were allowed to travel. Again no apology or explanation was given for this. Why this couldn't have been sorted sooner I have no idea. The handling of this situation was appalling - leaving people in London after midnight with no means to get to their destination.

After eventually being allowed to board as our carriage was on the train, we went to the Club Car. Sat in the Club Car were two members of staff who appeared to be having a meeting and were talking 'shop' with papers out all over the seats. We had come away on what we considered to be a holiday and did not want to sit next to two people conducting a business meeting. The language being used by these staff was something more akin to what I would expect to hear in a working mens club with one describing a route he had to memorise as a headf***. Certainly not what I was expecting to hear when it is described on your website as 'a place for our guests to unwind ahead of a busy day at their destination' and 'the perfect spot to either relax with a late-night drink'

When we returned to the clubcar for breakfast I have to say this was a disappointment as the food was all overcooked despite us being a few minutes earlier than requested on the breakfast booking form. Again the phrase used on your website 'our meals will make your journey unforgettable' is certainly not how we would have described it in a positive capacity.

This trip was something special for us as a treat and the issues we encountered and poor services definitely took the shine off our trip and we felt we had wasted our money. I sent an email of complaint to Caledonian and was finally offered an apology and a refund of just over £40 which nowhere near covers the dissapointment (less than 10% of the price we paid). This trip was a one off for us, but just thought I would share our experiences if someone else is thinking of bookng this.

items.title: NOT a good experience!
items.review_text:
This was only the second journey I'd taken on the Caledonian sleeper, the first... back in October 2022, I booked a classic sleeper cabin... costing £200... on arrival at Londons Euston station, I was met by the Caledonian staff at the platform, I was excited to be travelling in 'comfort', enjoy 'bespoke complimentary toiletries" and "the option to purchase breakfast from our extensive room service menu" the staff ushered me along, pointing me in the direction of my carriage.
I opened the door to my cabin, it was small, 2 small, narrow bunk beds and a sink... not something for those that have a phobia of small spaces! I pulled back the bottom bunk duvet to reveal someone elses hair in the bed, and on the pillow... the mattress protector had blood on it, which could clearly be seen through the thin sheet. 
I went into the corridor to look for staff, but couldn't find anyone. The sink was dirty, and the bespoke complimentary toiletries amounted to a bar of soap. I was disappointed and tired. 
I'd received an email earlier to tell me that due to a lack of staff, the club car was not serving hot food. I made my selection from the room service breakfast menu, hung it on my door handle in the corridor, and lay on top of the bed... listening to the occupants next door ordering drinks to their cabin, they were told there was no cabin service tonight. The cabin walls were so thin that I could hear a group of lads further along the carriage larking around, one of whom announced his manhood was the sweatiest it had ever been... in fact, you could hear the rolling stock going over the sleepers and everything inside and out.
I set my alarm, but I didn't sleep... on leaving the train the next morning, a member of staff I passed in the corridor asked if I'd received my breakfast order... I said I hadn't received anything, not even a courtesy call for my approaching station... he said he'd look into it.
For my second journey, and what will be my last on the Caledonian sleeper, I booked the seated carriage, costing £70. I arrived feeling positive about this journey... but soon to be greeted by the same expressionless staff, herding us like cattle onto the train.
My seat was very hard, not the "comfort seat" advertised... the headrest pushed my head forward, pressing the button on the seat, only moved the seated part forward a couple of inches... it didn't recline the seat at all. You were still sitting upright and weren't at all comfortable. 
The cabin lights remained on all night. Cold air was blowing out of the heating vents. The noise in the carriage was as though there was no insulation. You could hear and feel each bump on the rail. Come 5am, I hadn't slept, I was cold too so I went to the catering car. A couple of tables were laid out, with 3 cusomers sat having breakfast... the rest of the tables were taken with staff. I asked for a coffee... a member of staff got up from a single seat, so I sat down... the carriage was warm, so I was relieved to be able to sit somewhere warm and somewhat more comfortable... my coffee arrived, only to be told by staff that I couldn't drink it there because I'd come from the seats... it was takeaway only! 
I went back to my seat... looking at the station display in my carriage... "Next Station" has read the same station for a while now. I went online to check the CS timetable... it was now 06.40... according to their timetable, we should have arrived at the station displayed at 06.15? Long story short, I was taken to the train manager who hadn't realised the information displays weren't working. The train was, in fact, running 20 mins early, and that we had already passed the station I was supposed to get off at!! 
I couldn't bring myself to take my return journey on the Caledonian Sleeper for this trip... I was told it was too late to cancel, so I wasn't entitled to a refund. I booked at seat on Avanti West Coast for the return journey the next morning... a much better service.
I will not be spending my money with Caledonian sleeper again.

items.title: Horrible Journey!!!
items.review_text:
I was so looking forward to this journey, having planned it months in advance.  We travelled in the seated area, which had been hyped-up by the marketing as a real alternative to the cabins (beds).  I know that seats are not a full alternative to beds, but......

I managed to get half an hour of sleep at the very end of the journey, mainly because my body went into emergency shut-down through sheer desperation!  The seats are very very uncomfortable and the 'reclining' function is barely a slight tilt.  The leg room was appalling.  When going along to the toilet in the middle of the night, the sheer variety of sleeping positions adopted by my fellow (seated) travellers was like seeing a yoga class at their first meeting after having been given the instruction manual for the first time!

The toilet was full of pee and so, when my wife went to use the loo in the adjacent catering/club car, the staff pounced on her like the scene from the film, Titanic, where Leonardo DiCaprio's character is challenged when trying to leave 'steerage' class and escape from the rising waters through a higher class of accommodation.  A member of staff eventually allowed her to use the 'other' (classier?) loo and said that he would reset the first loo's electronics, which did clear the almost-to-the-brim level of pee in the loo back in our 'steerage' class.  [I then tried finding the Irish bar carriage (as per the film) where my wife and I could dance on the tables into the wee hours, but alas, this was a Scottish sleeper service!]

The train was excessively noisy considering the carriages are a modern design, although I suspect some of this is due to the track and not the train itself.  The supplied eye mask was effective but the ear-plugs, despite being a welcome addition, still allowed too much noise through.

On the plus side, the on-board 'guard' in the same passenger compartment as us was very friendly and welcoming throughout and did his best to reassign us to seats with marginally longer legroom.  He was a real asset to the company, to be fair to him, and deserves credit from his bosses!

The Business Model for this service seems fundamentally flawed in terms of the price and standard of the seated service and the huge jump to the prices for cabins with beds.  The "Mark 5" carriages are in use with other train operators and it would be quite simple to:  rip out all of the existing seats and dispose of them!  Purchase new, fully-reclining seats with more padding and better curvature around the edges.  Place the new seats back in the carriages with about a third of the seats missing and re-assign the seats with much greater distances between them to allow for reclining and for more appropriate legroom.  Yes, these "Mark 5" carriages have the ability to have the seats bolted down in a huge variety of different configurations, the holes for which are nicely hidden under the carpet, so let's not use 'it's too difficult' as a lame excuse for inaction!

With such new seats, passengers would happily pay the (currently) far-too-high ticket prices for far better reclining seats and you would get far more repeat custom.  Then, and only then, will your hyped-up marketing of these 'cattle-class' seats be more accurate and lead to an increase in patronage.  Alternatively, keep the current seats but advertise them as 'steerage' class and put up posters of old Leonardo Di-C in place of the current photos on your website.

Come on Caledonian, get a team together in a room and sort this out.  You have a lucrative market to access and so much untapped customer base to target!  But with the numerous less-than-favourable reviews on this site - and others - many will continue to use other (seated) operators or fly (booooo, it's bad for the environment!) and book a hotel at the other end - which still somehow ends up being cheaper than your cabin prices!!!!!

I am really gutted to have ended a truly excellent week in Edinburgh with my wife, by having to endure the worst train journey I have ever had - leaving me tired and certainly not 'refreshed' (as claimed by your marketing!) and having to have wasted much of today catching up on my lack of sleep from the previous night's journey with Caledonian.

Come on people, get your act together and sort out this service that has so much potential.  Perhaps, as a start, why not try inviting real customers to work with you on this, rather than using some lame-##s consultancy firm that has about as much clue as a clueless thing!

items.title: So disappointing - you couldn't make it up!
items.review_text:
My wife and I travelled from London Euston to Inverness on the Caledonian sleeper recently    We had purchased a club cabin and were very much looking forward to the experience.    The website promises a “hotel experience”.   Dinner in the Club Car, described as “the beating heart of Caledonian Sleeper”, was claimed to be a “showcase of the very best produce that Scotland has to offer” 
What a major disappointment!   First of all, we had been told that we could reserve dinner when we checked in for the train and that could be done on the Euston concourse. Wrong, there is no check-in on the concourse.   Nevertheless, we were at the front of the queue but when we boarded we were told that there was no reserving and it was first come first served.    So, we left our bags in the cabin and went straight down to the club car but it was already full.     There was only one club car for numerous sleeper coaches and a single diner coach clearly had no chance of getting close to serving the numbers of people wanting to dine.     It seems that the people in the know (i.e. had travelled before) simply sent one of their party to grab a table before even going to their cabin (top tip), so there was probably no chance of first time Caledonian travellers like ourselves getting a table.    
Ok, so the diner was full but we were told that we could reserve for a second sitting which would be approximately one hour after departure.   This was getting late (10.30pm?) but if we wanted to eat and enjoy the start of our holiday there was no other choice, so we agreed.
Back in the club cabin we also found disappointment.   Both bunks were ready for the night-time (i.e. top bunk down) so there was really no-where to sit comfortably while we waited for dinner.   Also, the cabins are unbelievably narrow.  With the bunks down the width to move in, out or around is not much more than the depth of a suitcase.
After our hour we went back down to the diner and were delighted to find that a table was just coming free.   We were given the menu, which looked very nice, only to be told that they were sold out of almost everything.   The waiter had an interesting way of describing it.   For example, there were five items on the starter menu and he said to us (completely straight-faced) that they had everything on the menu tonight except…..    He then reeled off four of the five items on the starter menu.   Similarly, there was almost nothing for the main course and no desserts left at all except a single child’s menu brownie (which we had – two spoons).   Hardly “the very best that Scotland has to offer”.  The same story for wine and drinks.   It was all so bad that all you could do was laugh in the end.  A true joke.
We went back to the cabin and then discovered that the toilet flush in our cabin wasn’t working.   After several calls to the steward they appeared to get it working.  It worked for a while but then stopped again in the morning before we got into Inverness.  Breakfast was a cold bacon roll.
I have travelled all over the world, including a variety of sleeper trains, and this is one of the worst experiences I have had when you consider the prices charged and the grossly over-hyped marketing displayed on the website, Facebook and elsewhere.    
Reading other reviews, I believe that this was not an isolated incident but similar to those experienced by many customers.    Blaming Covid for these events is not an excuse either.   There are several ways the events described could have been avoided but in each case it would have probably cost more money.   I am left with the impression that the management of the company is focusing on maximising profit rather than customer satisfaction. 
Finally, the staff on board were great.    They tried to do what they could to help but, it seems to me, the management of the company is putting them in an impossible position.

items.title: Never been so  cold
items.review_text: Never been so  cold. Let's hope new stock had heating.
